Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: A violent assault is taking place in a public area, with bystanders in danger
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, my little brother grinning at me, helmet askew, as he eyed the steep, cracked ramp. “Watch this, I’ve got it,” he said, determination in his voice. As his older sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. My heart pounded with worry—one wrong move and he could break a bone, or worse. But just as he set his board down, my police radio crackled to life. There was a violent assault happening just a block away, with bystanders at risk. As an officer, I was sworn to protect the public, to respond without hesitation. I could already hear the panic in the dispatcher’s voice, the urgency in the background. My brother looked up at me, waiting for my encouragement, trusting me to be there. I felt torn in two, the weight of both uniforms—family and duty—pressing down on me, each demanding I choose them first.
